'Trump's diplomacy, hastily and wrongly labeled as isolationist, is interventionist'
subhead: The peace agreement between Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, negotiated by the US on June 27, has more to do with the US' interest in critical minerals and its rivalry with China than with peace in Africa, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: French detainees in Iran charged with spying for Israel
Trump says Israel agrees to terms on ceasefire in Gaza
Polish support for Ukraine's EU bid is eroding
subhead: The election of nationalist Karol Nawrocki as president highlights the concerns within a segment of Polish society over the prospect of its neighbor's integration into the European Union.

title: 'To those rejected by the US, China opens its arms wider'
subhead: Xi Jinping is methodically weaving his economic and trade web − particularly in Africa and Brazil − as a counterweight to Donald Trump's United States. But criticism has emerged in these countries over the unequal sharing of value between them and the Chinese giant, says Le Monde's Harold Thibault in his column.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote about Anna Wintour
subhead: The 75-year-old fashion icon announced on June 26 that she was stepping down as editor-in-chief of the American magazine Vogue. She was first mentioned in this newspaper on October 22, 1997, before coming under closer scrutiny with the release of the film The Devil Wears Prada.

title: In Germany, Syrians still do not feel fully assimilated after 10 years
subhead: '2015-2025: Europe's migration crisis' (2/5). Thanks to former chancellor Angela Merkel's asylum policy, Germany has taken in nearly half the Syrians seeking refuge in Europe since 2015. One of them, Amer Alqadi, a 39-year-old married father and naturalized citizen, believes that while the country still needs immigrants, its political climate has grown more tense.
byline: By Julia Pascual (Berlin, special correspondent) and Samuel Gratacap

title: Trump announces tariff rate deal with Vietnam
Israel limits entry of baby formula in Gaza as infants die of hunger
subhead: While waiting to enter Gaza on a medical aid mission, an American doctor watched Israeli security forces confiscate the cans of powdered baby formula packed in his luggage. The vital product is desperately lacking in the Palestinian enclave, where about 50 children have died of hunger since March.

title: In Japan, a manga artist has predicted a disaster in early July, causing a drop in tourism
subhead: The 'prediction' made by a manga author has sparked panic and a decline in bookings around July 5, the day that she claims an earthquake will trigger a massive tsunami. Authorities have reiterated that it is impossible to predict earthquakes.

title: In Hungary, a decade of dismantling asylum rights
subhead: '2015-2025: Europe's migration crisis' (1/5). In response to the arrival of hundreds of thousands of asylum seekers in the summer of 2015, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban built a fence in the south of the country to push them away.
byline: By Julia Pascual (Budapest (Hungary), special corrspondent) and Samuel Gratacap
